questionList.questionText: A new test is devised to measure the serum level of a specific protein.  A sample of blood is taken from a patient, and the new test is performed 3 times with results of 162, 186, and 247 IU/dL.  Using the traditional reference test (considered the gold standard), the patient's serum protein level is determined to be 184 IU/dL.  A measurement within 5% of the reference test value is considered accurate.  Based on these results, the new test most likely has which of the following characteristics?
questionList.explanationText:
A measurement tool should be both precise and accurate to be useful in the clinical setting.  Precision and accuracy are defined as follows:

  • Precision (reliability) is the ability of a test to reproduce identical or similar results with repeat measurements (eg, two bottom figures).

  • Accuracy (validity) is the ability of a test to measure what it is supposed to measure.  For a test to be accurate, its results should be equivalent to the results obtained with a gold standard (ie, best conventional test available) on the same individual (eg, two right figures).

A precise test gives similar or very close results on repeat measurements.  In this example, repeat measurements of the same sample yielded different results (ie, 162, 186, and 247 IU/dL); therefore, the new test has low precision (Choices A and B).

The value given by the reference test for the patient is 184 IU/dL, with accurate values considered to be those within 5% of the reference value:

Lower cutoff:  184 − (184 × 0.05) = 174.8

Upper cutoff:  184 + (184 × 0.05) = 193.2

Only 1 of the repeat measurements (186 IU/dL) is within 5% of the reference value (range: 174.8-193.2 IU/dL).  Therefore, the new test has low accuracy (Choice C).

Educational objective:
A precise tool is one that consistently provides a very similar or identical value when measuring a fixed quantity.  An accurate tool is one that provides a measurement similar to the actual value or within a specified range of a reference value (as reflected by a gold-standard measurement).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Accuracy and precision

answerChoiceList.choice: Precision and accuracy cannot be determined

questionList.questionText: A cohort study was conducted to assess the relationship between high saturated fat consumption and the occurrence of colorectal carcinoma among women.  A group of women aged 40-65 was selected.  The baseline saturated fat consumption was calculated using a food questionnaire, and the cohort was followed for seven years for the development of colon cancer.  The study showed that women with high baseline saturated fat consumption have four times the risk of colorectal cancer in a 7-year period, compared to women with low fat consumption (RR = 4.0, 95% CI = 1.5 - 6.5).  According to the study results, what percent of colorectal carcinoma in women with high fat consumption could be attributed to their diet?
questionList.explanationText:
Attributable risk percent (ARP) or etiologic fraction is an important measure of the impact of a risk factor being studied.  ARP represents the excess risk in a population that can be explained by exposure to a particular risk factor.  It is calculated by subtracting the risk in the unexposed population (baseline risk) from the risk in the exposed population, and dividing the result by the risk in the exposed population:

ARP = (risk in exposed - risk in unexposed)/risk in exposed.

An easier way to calculate the ARP is to derive it from the relative risk (RR):

ARP = (RR - 1)/RR.

In this case, ARP = (4.0 - 1)/4.0 = 0.75 (75%).  According to the study results, 75% of colorectal carcinoma in the high consumption group was attributable to high saturated fat intake.

Educational Objective:
ARP represents the excess risk in the exposed population that can be attributed to the risk factor.  It can be easily derived from the relative risk using the following formula: ARP = (RR - 1)/RR.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Risk

questionList.questionText: Two cross-sectional studies were conducted using different questionnaires to determine the prevalence of over-the-counter analgesics use in a population.  The first study showed a prevalence of 7.5% (95% confidence interval 6.0 - 9.0), and the second study demonstrated a prevalence of 7.3% (95% confidence interval 6.9 - 7.6).  If the true prevalence of over-the-counter analgesics use in the population is 7.4%, which of the following statements about the results of the study is the most accurate?
questionList.explanationText:
Precision is the measure of random error in the study.  The study is precise if the results are not scattered widely; this is reflected by a tight confidence interval.  The first study has a wider confidence interval compared to the second study; therefore, the second study is more precise.

(Choices A and B) Specificity and sensitivity are measures of validity.  The sensitivity and specificity of the questionnaires used in these studies cannot be determined from the given information.

(Choices C and D) Validity and accuracy are measures of systematic error (bias).  Accuracy is reduced if the result does not reflect the true value of the parameter measured.  Increasing the sample size increases the precision of the study, but does not affect accuracy.  In our case, the results of both studies are pretty close to the true value, and are thus seemingly accurate.

Educational Objective:
Precision is the measure of random error.  The tighter the confidence interval, the more precise the result. Increasing the sample size increases precision.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Accuracy and precision

answerChoiceList.choice: The first study results are more specific
The second study results are more sensitive
The first study results are more valid
The first study results are more accurate
The second study results are more precise

questionList.questionText: A large case-control study was conducted to assess the relationship between tampon use and toxic shock syndrome (TSS).  The odds ratio for tampon use among patients with TSS compared to healthy subjects (controls) was reported as 5.0 (95% confidence interval [4.7-5.2], p <0.01).  The authors concluded that the risk of TSS was approximately 5 times higher in tampon users; this was based on the assumption that odds ratio is a good approximation of relative risk in this study.  Which of the following best supports this assumption?
questionList.explanationText:
Relative risk (RR) can be calculated in cohort studies by comparing the risk (incidence) of disease among exposed individuals to the risk among unexposed individuals.  Cohort studies are potentially costly and time-consuming, but case-control studies are relatively inexpensive, less time-consuming, and popular for exploring exposure-disease associations.  However, RR cannot be directly calculated in case-control studies as such studies do not follow patients over time or measure disease incidence.  The exposure odds ratio (OR) is a measure of association commonly used in case-control studies.  It compares the odds of exposure among individuals with the disease (cases) to the odds of exposure among individuals without the disease (controls).  If the disease is rare (low disease prevalence), disease incidence (number of new cases) is typically low, and the OR generally approximates the RR.  This is called the "rare disease assumption."

Mathematically: given standard contingency tables, RR = [a / (a + b)] / [c / (c + d)] and OR = ad / bc.  When the disease is rare, a and c represent small quantities.  Therefore, a is negligible compared to b, and c is negligible compared to d; this results in a reasonable mathematical approximation of RR, where RR becomes approximately ad / bc, which equals OR.

In addition to the "rare disease assumption," OR also approximates RR (regardless of disease incidence) when the cases and controls used in a study are representative of individuals with and without the disease in the overall population (with regard to the exposure of interest).

(Choice B)  The results of the study (OR = 5.0) suggest that the exposure (tampon use) is associated with the disease (toxic shock syndrome).  However, this does not affect the approximation of OR to RR.

(Choices A, D, and E)  The p-value <0.01 indicates that the OR is statistically significant.  A large sample size decreases the p-value for the OR and makes the confidence interval narrower.  As a result, the precision of the estimate increases.  However, this does not affect the approximation of OR to RR.

Educational objective:
In a case-control study, if the outcome is uncommon in the population, the odds ratio is a close approximation of the relative risk ("rare disease assumption").
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Risk

answerChoiceList.choice: The confidence interval for the odds ratio is narrow
The exposure is associated with the disease
The incidence of toxic shock syndrome is low
The odds ratio is highly statistically significant

questionList.questionText: A study was conducted to assess the relationship between race and end-stage renal disease.  Two groups of pathologists independently studied specimens from 1,000 kidney biopsies.  The first group of pathologists was aware of the race of the patient from whom the biopsy came, while the second group was blinded from the patient's race.  The first group reported "hypertensive nephropathy" much more frequently for Black patients than the second group.  This study best demonstrates which of the following types of bias?
questionList.explanationText:
Observer bias occurs when the investigator's decision is adversely affected by knowledge of the exposure status.  In this case, some pathologists' decisions were influenced by the fact that hypertensive nephropathy is a common cause of endstage renal disease in the Black population.  The pathologists who were blinded to the subjects' race were not under this influence, so their interpretation was more unbiased.

(Choice A)  Confounding is present when at least part of the exposure-disease relationship can be explained by another variable (confounder).  No information on possible confounders is given in this scenario.

(Choice B)  Respondent bias is present when the outcome is obtained by the patient's response, and not by objective diagnostic methods (e.g., migraine headache).  In this case, the diagnosis was ascertained via kidney biopsy.

(Choice C)  Recall bias results from inaccurate recall of past exposure by patients.  It is not applicable to this case.

(Choice D)  Selection bias results from the manner in which the subjects are selected for the study, or from the selective losses from the follow-up.

Educational objective:
Observer bias occurs when the investigator's decision is adversely affected by knowledge of the exposure status.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Bias

questionList.questionText: The physical therapy department at a local university hospital participated in a randomized, prospective, parallel-group study on the clinical effectiveness of 3 different exercise programs (Program A, Program B, and Program C) in patients with osteoarthritis (OA) of knee joint.  Researchers randomized 90 patients with OA of the knee joint into 3 groups of 30 patients each.  The primary endpoint of the study was the distance walked (in meters) in the 6 minute walk test (6MWT).  Assuming all conditions for inference are met, which of the following statistical tests is most appropriate to compare the distance walked (in meters) among exercise programs?
questionList.explanationText:
Dependent variable

Qualitative (categorical)

Quantitative

Independent variable

Qualitative (categorical)

Chi-square, logistic regression*

t test, ANOVA, linear regression

Quantitative

Logistic regression*

Correlation, linear regression

*Dependent variable must be dichotomous.

ANOVA =  analysis of variance.

Variables are broadly classified as qualitative (ie, categorical) or quantitative (eg, continuous) based on the scale of measurement.  Qualitative variables (eg, type of treatment, blood type) represent categories or groups, whereas quantitative variables (eg, temperature, glucose level) represent numerical values.  The scale of measurement of the dependent (eg, outcome) and independent (eg, exposure, risk factor) variables in a study determines the correct statistical test for any given situation.

The analysis of variance (ANOVA) test compares the means of ≥3 groups.  It requires a categorical independent variable (eg, exposure) that is used to divide study participants into ≥3 groups and a quantitative dependent variable (eg, outcome) for which an average (eg, mean) is calculated.  In this study:

  • The categorical independent variable is type of exercise program given to 3 different groups of patients with osteoarthritis (OA) of knee joint: Program A, Program B, and Program C

  • The quantitative dependent variable is distance walked (in meters) in the 6 minute walk test (6MWT), for which a mean can be calculated.

An ANOVA test can determine whether there is a statistically significant difference in the mean number of meters walked in the 6MWT among patients with OA of knee joint given different exercise programs.  A large, statistically significant difference between groups indicates that different exercise programs are associated with significant changes in the mean number of meters walked in the 6MWT.

(Choice B)  The chi-square test evaluates the association between 2 categorical variables, as in a study evaluating the association between sex (male, female) and myocardial infarction (presence of myocardial infarction, absence of myocardial infarction).

(Choice C)  A correlation analysis uses the correlation coefficient to describe the linear relationship between 2 quantitative variables, as in a study evaluating the linear relationship between hours of sleep and irritability score.

(Choice D)  Relative risk estimates the association between a categorical independent variable (eg, exposure, risk factor) and a categorical dependent variable (eg, outcome), as in a cohort study that estimates the association between exposure to secondhand smoke and lung cancer.

(Choice E)  The two-sample t-test compares the mean of a quantitative variable between 2 groups, as in a study comparing the mean number of meters walked in the 6MWT (quantitative variable) between a group of patients assigned to an exercise program and another not assigned to an exercise program.

Educational objective:
The analysis of variance test compares the mean of ≥3 groups.  The test requires a quantitative dependent variable (eg, outcome) and a categorical independent variable (eg, exposure, risk factor).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Statistical tests

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Statistical methodology: IV.  Analysis of variance, analysis of covariance, and multivariate analysis of variance.

questionList.questionText: A clinical trial is performed to study the effect of a new antihypertensive drug.  If the subjects of the study change their behavior because they are aware that they are under observation, what type of bias will take place?
questionList.explanationText:
Bias poses a threat to the validity of any study.  A sample which is not representative of the population is said to be a biased sample.  In this vignette, a biased sample with Hawthorne effect is described.

Hawthorne effect can be defined as the tendency of a study population to affect the outcome because these people are aware that they are being studied.  This awareness leads to a consequent change in behavior while under observation, thereby seriously affecting the validity of the study.  Hawthorne effect is commonly seen in studies that concern behavioral outcomes or outcomes that can be influenced by behavioral changes.  In order to minimize the potential of the Hawthorne effect, studied subjects can be kept unaware that they are being studied; however, this may pose ethical problems.  Randomized control trials have a sense of uncertainty and risk due to randomization, which may be more potent behavior modifiers than mere observation.

(Choice A)  Sample distortion bias is seen when the estimate of exposure and outcome association is biased because the study sample is not representative of the target population with respect to the joint distribution of exposure and outcome.

(Choice B)  Information bias occurs due to the imperfect assessment of association between the exposure and outcome as a result of errors in the measurement of exposure and outcome status.  It can be minimized by using standardized techniques for surveillance and measurement of outcomes, as well as trained observers to measure the exposure and outcome.

(Choice C)  Confounding bias occurs due to the presence of one or more variables associated independently with both the exposure and the outcome.  For example, cigarette smoking can be a confounding factor in studying the association between maternal alcohol drinking and low birth weight babies, as cigarette smoking is independently associated with both alcohol consumption and low birth weight babies.

Educational objective:
Know the different kinds of bias, which can decrease the validity of study results.  Hawthorne effect is the tendency of the study population to affect the outcome since they are aware that they are being studied.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Bias

questionList.questionText: An open-label randomized parallel-arm active study evaluated the safety and efficacy of a continuous infusion of potassium chloride versus an existing intermittent infusion regimen in critically ill adults with plasma potassium concentration between 2.5 mmol/L and 3.8 mmol/L.  The primary outcome was the difference in mean plasma potassium concentration over time between the 2 groups.  The study reported a difference in mean plasma potassium concentration over time between groups of 0.2 mmol/L.  A 90% confidence interval (CI) showed that the difference was statistically significant.  What would be the effect on the width and significance of the CI if the confidence level is increased to 95%?
questionList.explanationText:
A C% confidence interval (CI) is a range of plausible values calculated from sample data that captures the true population value with a C% confidence level.  The confidence level C refers to how often a CI includes the true population value if the process is repeated multiple times.

A CI to estimate a population value (eg, difference of 2 population means) is constructed by taking a sample value (eg, difference of 2 sample means) and adding and subtracting a margin of error based on a desired confidence level C.

  • A 90% CI has a 90% confidence level and captures the central 90% of the distribution.
  • A 95% CI has a 95% confidence level and captures the central 95% of the distribution.

Therefore, for the same data, a CI with a greater confidence level (eg, 95% CI) is always wider (eg, capturing 95% of the distribution) than a CI with a lower confidence level (eg, 90% CI).

In this question, the difference in mean plasma potassium concentration over time between groups is estimated at 0.2 mmol/L, and the 90% CI showed that the difference was statistically significant (ie, the CI excluded 0, the null value for a difference).  Increasing the confidence level from a 90% CI to a 95% CI results in an interval that is wider than the 90% CI (Choices A and B).

However, because the boundaries of the 90% CI are not provided, it is not possible to determine whether the wider 95% CI will exclude 0 (the null value).  For example, for the narrower 90% CI, the lower and upper boundaries may both be positive values; but for the wider 95% CI, the lower boundary may be a negative value whereas the upper boundary may be a positive value.  Therefore, the statistical significance of the 95% CI cannot be determined (Choice C).

Educational objective:
A confidence interval (CI) with a greater confidence level is always wider than a CI with a lower confidence level for the same data.  A CI for a difference in means is significant if the interval excludes the null value (ie, 0), and it is not significant if the interval includes the null value.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: P-value and confidence interval

answerChoiceList.choice: Narrower Significant
Narrower Unable to determine
Wider Significant
Wider Unable to determine

questionList.answerHeader: Width of 95% CIStatistical significance

questionList.questionText:
A new serum biomarker for the diagnosis of early-stage pancreatic cancer is being studied by a group of investigators.  The marker represents a fetal antigen that has minimal expression in healthy adults but has increased expression in pancreatic cancer cells.  The sensitivity and specificity of the marker were determined at various serum concentration cutoff points using surgical biopsy results as the gold standard.  The following receiver operating characteristic curve is constructed.

Point X on the curve best corresponds to which of the following?
questionList.explanationText:
Many quantitative diagnostic tests are based on substance values or parameters that are continuous in nature.  Examples of such variables include blood sugar levels, arterial blood pressure, body temperature, and serum enzyme levels.  In order to be useful for diagnostic purposes, an arbitrary cutoff point is chosen to separate normal from abnormal results.  Patients with abnormal values are considered to test positive for the disease; those with normal values are considered to test negative for the disease.

The ROC curve emphasizes the importance of choosing the appropriate cutoff value when designing a diagnostic test based on continuous values.  It shows how the sensitivity and specificity of the test change as the cutoff point is raised and lowered.  At any particular cutoff point, there is a trade-off between sensitivity and specificity.  Changing the cutoff point to increase the number of patients with the disease who test positive will increase the true-positive rate (which is directly proportional to sensitivity), but it will also increase the number of patients without the disease who test positive (increasing the false-positive rate, which is inversely proportional to specificity).  As a result, specificity usually decreases as sensitivity increases and vice-versa.

At point X, the true-positive rate (sensitivity) is very close to 1.0 (ie, sensitivity is near 100%), while the false-positive rate (1 - specificity) is near 0.8 (ie, specificity is close to 20%) (Choice A).

Educational objective:
The receiver operating characteristic curve of a quantitative diagnostic test demonstrates the trade-off between the test's sensitivity and specificity at various cutoff points.  Changing the cutoff point to increase the true-positive rate (directly proportional to sensitivity) will also increase the false-positive rate (inversely proportional to specificity).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Receiver Operating Characteristic

answerChoiceList.choice: 0.95 0.18
0.95 0.86
0.16 0.86
0.16 0.18

questionList.answerHeader: SensitivitySpecificity

questionList.questionText: In an intensive care unit, 10 measurements of a patient's systolic blood pressure were obtained over several hours using an intra-arterial cannula.  The maximal value recorded was 120 mm Hg, and the minimal value was 100 mm Hg.  If the next measurement shows a value of 240 mm Hg, which of the following is most likely to happen?
questionList.explanationText:
An outlier is defined as an extreme and unusual value observed in a dataset.  It may be the result of a recording error, a measurement error, or a natural phenomenon.  An outlier can affect the measures of central tendency (mean, median, mode) as well as the measures of dispersion (eg, standard deviation).

The mean (mathematical average) is extremely sensitive to outliers and easily shifts toward them, especially with a small sample size.  In this case, the value of 240 mm Hg is an outlier and would cause the mean to increase more than the median or the mode, especially given that there were only 10 total measurements obtained prior to this value, all of which were between 100 and 120 mm Hg.

(Choice B)  The median tends to be more resistant to outliers because it splits an ordered dataset in its middle, where the observations usually do not differ much from one another.  For example, the median for the dataset {10, 10, 11, 12, 12} is 11, which splits the dataset in half (comes between {10, 10} and {12, 12}); by adding an additional value of 12, the median will shift to the value between {11, 12}, ie, 11.5.  In this case, adding the value of 240 mm Hg will shift the median; however, the change is unlikely to be great, as the first 10 measurements all lie between 100 mm Hg and 120 mm Hg.

(Choice C)  The mode (the most frequently observed value) is less likely to be affected by outliers.  For example, if the value of 115 mm Hg was recorded most often among the first 10 measurements, then 115 mm Hg would be the mode; having an additional value of 240 mm Hg in the dataset would not change that.

(Choice D)  The range is the difference between the maximal value and the minimal value.  In this case, the range will change from 20 mm Hg (= 120 − 100 mm Hg) to 140 mm Hg (= 240 − 100 mm Hg).

(Choice E)  The standard deviation (a measure of dispersion within the dataset) is sensitive to outliers because outliers significantly increase the dispersion.  A value of 240 mm Hg would very likely affect the standard deviation of a dataset of 10 elements, all of which lie between 100 mm Hg and 120 mm Hg.

Educational objective:
An outlier is defined as an extreme and unusual value observed in a dataset.  The mean is very sensitive to outliers and easily shifts toward them.  The median and mode are more resistant to outliers.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Central tendency (mean, median, mode, outliers)

answerChoiceList.choice: The mean will increase more than the median or the mode
The median will increase more than the mean or the mode
The mode will increase more than the mean or the median
The standard deviation will not change

questionList.questionText:
A study evaluated the predictive effect of inflammatory molecule intercellular adhesion molecule-1 (ICAM-1) level on the prognosis of acute ischemic stroke (AIS).  The study included 300 patients with AIS who were treated at 3 local hospitals.  Demographic data were collected, and blood samples were obtained within 24 hours of admission to detect the clinical indicators.  The functional prognosis was measured using the modified Rankin Scale (mRS) 3 months after stroke.  Poor prognosis was defined as an mRS score ≥3.  Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay was used to determine serum ICAM-1 levels.  The receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve analysis for serum ICAM-1 level in AIS patients is shown below.

The labeled points in the ROC graph represent 4 theoretically possible cut point values.  Which of the following describes the cut point value labeled E?
questionList.explanationText:
A receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve for a given diagnostic test plots sensitivity on the y-axis and (1 − specificity), or equivalently (100% − specificity), on the x-axis.  The curve can help determine the best cutoff threshold (ie, the value that determines if a given test result is positive or negative) to use depending on the optimal desired parameters for sensitivity and specificity.

Sensitivity (ie, test's ability to correctly identify patients with disease as positive) represents the rate of true positives.  Specificity (ie, test's ability to correctly identify patients without disease as negative) represents the rate of true negatives.  Therefore, (1 − specificity) represents the rate of false positives.

In the ROC graph shown, the cut point E has:

  • a rate of true positives (ie, sensitivity) of 0.0 (it lies on the x-axis).

  • a rate of false positives (ie, 1 − specificity) of 1.0 (or 100%).

This means that, at this cut point, there are no true positives and all results are false positives.  In other words, all positive test results are truly false positives (Choices B, C, and D).  Given the 100% rate of false positives, the cut point would mislabel healthy individuals as sick (ie, falsely positive) 100% of the time.

Educational objective:
For a test that is 0% sensitive and 0% specific, all positive test results are false positives.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Receiver Operating Characteristic

answerChoiceList.choice: All positive test results are false positives
All positive test results are true positives

questionList.questionText: In a large population with an almost negligible growth rate and minimal migration, the incidence of type 2 diabetes mellitus is 3 cases per 1,000 individuals a year, and has been stable for the last 30 years.  However, the prevalence of type 2 diabetes mellitus has increased progressively over the same period.  Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this trend over time?
questionList.explanationText:
Incidence and prevalence are 2 important concepts in epidemiology that measure disease occurrence in a population:

  • Incidence (incident cases) refers to the number of new cases of disease that develop in a specific population over a specified time period.
  • By contrast, prevalence quantifies existing cases of disease in the population at a particular point in time.

Prevalence of disease depends on how fast cases develop and on the duration of the disease.  When a population has reached a stable condition, as suggested by a negligible growth rate (ie, neither growing nor shrinking in size) and minimal migration, the prevalence of disease can be approximated by considering the incidence and the duration of disease in the following manner:

Prevalence = (Incidence) × (Duration of disease)

In this case, the specific population has a rising prevalence but a stable incidence of diabetes.  In other words, more people are being documented as having diabetes although the number of people being newly diagnosed each year remains the same.  Because incidence is stable, the increasing prevalence can likely be attributed to factors that prolong the duration of the disease, such as improvements in quality of care and disease management, which may lead to a significant increase in life expectancy.

(Choice A)  Decreased length of hospital stay is not helpful in explaining the increased prevalence described in this case.

(Choice B)  A high mortality rate in patients diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus would result in a decrease, rather than an increase, in prevalence.

(Choice D)  Increased diagnostic accuracy would significantly increase both incidence and prevalence of disease.

(Choice E)  Selective survival bias refers to the selection process of prevalent cases rather than incident cases in a case-control study.

Educational objective:
An increasing prevalence but stable incidence of a disease can be attributed to factors that prolong the duration of the disease (eg, improved quality of care and disease management).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Prevalence and incidence

answerChoiceList.choice: High mortality in patients with diabetes

questionList.questionText: A group of researchers conducted a case-control study to examine the association between epidermal growth factor (EGF) gene polymorphism and colorectal cancer (CRC).  The study determined EGF A61G polymorphism by using PCR-restriction fragment length polymorphism method in 350 CRC cases and 350 controls.  A different group of researchers decided to replicate the initial case-control study and recruited 700 CRC cases and 700 controls.  Which of the following is a major advantage of the replication study?
questionList.explanationText:
In this example, 2 case-control studies are conducted to examine the association between epidermal growth factor gene polymorphism and colorectal cancer (CRC).  The first study recruited 350 CRC cases and 350 controls, and the replication study recruited 700 CRC cases and 700 controls.  The replication study doubled the number of cases and controls, so it had a larger sample size than the first study.

A study's sample size has a direct effect on its statistical power.  Statistical power is the probability of rejecting a false null hypothesis H0 (eg, stating that there is an association when one truly exists).  It is the complement of the probability of a type II error, which is the probability of failing to reject a false H0.

Studies with larger sample sizes have greater statistical power, and consequently a lower probability of a type II error, than studies with smaller sample sizes.  Therefore, the replication study is less likely to fail to reject a false H0 (ie, has a lower probability of a type II error).

(Choice A)  A study controls for potential confounders during its design phase (eg, randomization, matching) or analytical phase (eg, stratification, regression).  A study with a smaller sample size can control for potential confounders as much as a study with a larger sample size.

(Choice B)  Negative predictive value (ie, proportion of subjects who truly do not have the disease among those with a negative test result) and positive predictive value (ie, proportion of subjects who truly have the disease among those with a positive test result) are performance parameters of diagnostic tests.  The studies are not evaluating the performance of a diagnostic test.

(Choice C)  Sensitivity (ie, proportion of subjects who have a positive test result among all those with disease) and specificity (ie, proportion of subjects who have a negative test result among all those without disease) are performance parameters of a diagnostic test.  The studies are not evaluating the performance of a diagnostic test.

(Choice E)  The correct classification of cases does not depend on sample size; instead, it depends on how clearly a case is defined in a particular study.

Educational objective:
Studies with larger sample sizes have greater statistical power, and consequently a lower probability of a type II error, than studies with smaller sample sizes.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Hypothesis testing

answerChoiceList.choice: Higher negative and positive predictive values
Lower probability of a type II error
More likely to correctly classify cases

questionList.questionText: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office due to a self-palpated breast mass.  After appropriate work-up, an image-guided core biopsy of the mass is performed.  The results of the core biopsy return as negative for malignancy; however, the results showed both atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) and atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH).  The patient understands that having ADH and ALH significantly increases her chances of developing breast cancer and is concerned.  She asks how likely it is for women with ADH and ALH and who have a negative biopsy to truly be cancer-free.  Which of the following measures best addresses this patient's question?
questionList.explanationText:
The predictive value (PV) of a test is the probability that the test result (ie, positive, negative) reflects the true disease status (ie, disease, no disease).  Positive and negative PVs are defined as follows:

  • Positive predictive value (PPV) determines how likely it is that a patient with a positive test result truly has the disease.

  • Negative predictive value (NPV) determines how likely it is that a patient with a negative test result truly does not have the disease.

Positive and negative PVs are directly related to the pretest probability of disease (often estimated by disease prevalence in a given population).  Assuming all other factors remain constant, PPV increases with increasing prevalence and NPV decreases with increasing prevalence.

In this case, a woman receives a negative breast biopsy result.  Based on biopsy findings, she has benign breast disease (ie, atypical ductal and lobular hyperplasia) that increases her risk for breast cancer.  She asks about the likelihood that women with the same risk factor profile (ie, similar pretest probability of disease) and who have a negative biopsy result are truly cancer-free (Choice C).  Therefore, the measure that addresses this patient's question is NPV.

In women with a higher risk factor profile (ie, higher pretest probability of disease), the predictive value of negative biopsy results (ie, NPV) may be lower.

(Choice A)  Accuracy determines how precisely a test identifies patients with disease as positive and patients without disease as negative, not the likelihood of a patient with a negative test result truly being disease-free.

(Choices D and E)  Sensitivity determines the percentage of patients with disease who will have a positive test result.  Specificity determines the percentage of patients with no disease who will have a negative test result.  These measures describe the performance of diagnostic tests and are not affected by pretest probability of disease (or disease prevalence).  In contrast, this patient is asking about the probability of disease given a test result.

Educational objective:
Negative predictive value (NPV) determines the likelihood that a patient with a negative test result truly does not have the disease.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Sensitivity, specificity, NPV, PPV

questionList.questionText: A new rapid diagnostic test for respiratory infections is evaluated on a population in which 30% of individuals have a respiratory infection.  The new test is 90% sensitive and 80% specific.  Which of the following is closest to the probability that an individual will be correctly classified by a test?
questionList.explanationText:
Positive condition

Negative condition

Positive test result

TP

FP

PPV =
TP / (TP + FP)

Negative test result

FN

TN

NPV =
TN / (TN + FN)

Sensitivity =

TP / (TP + FN)

Specificity =

TN / (TN + FP)

FN = false negative; FP = false positive; NPV = negative predictive value; PPV = positive predictive value; TN = true negative; TP = true positive.

Accuracy is the probability that an individual is correctly classified by a test.  It is calculated as the sum of the number of individuals who are correctly classified (ie, true positives [TP] and true negatives [TN]) divided by the total number of individuals tested (ie, TP + TN + false positives [FP] + false negatives [FN]):

Accuracy = (TP + TN) / (TP + FP + TN + FN)

TP, FP, TN, and FN can be determined by constructing a 2 × 2 table based on the given prevalence, sensitivity, and specificity.

  • Respiratory infection prevalence is 30%.  The sample size is not given, so assume a sample size of 100: 100 × 0.30 = 30 individuals have a respiratory infection and 100 − 30 = 70 do not.

  • Test sensitivity (ie, probability of an infected individual testing positive) is 90%, so TP = 30 × 0.90 = 27 and FN = 30 − 27 = 3.

  • Test specificity (ie, probability of an uninfected individual testing negative) is 80%, so TN = 70 × 0.80 = 56 and FP = 70 − 56 = 14.

Test result

Infection

No infection

Total

Positive

27
(TP)

14
(FP)

41

Negative

3
(FN)

56
(TN)

59

Total

30

70

100
(TP + FP + TN + FN)

Based on these data:

Accuracy = (27 + 56) / (27 + 14 + 3 + 56) = (83) / (100) = 0.83

Therefore, the probability that an individual will be correctly classified is 0.83.

When the sample size is not given, a value of 100 (or 1,000) is commonly used to simplify calculations (accuracy does not change with different sample sizes).

(Choice A)  0.13 is the negative likelihood ratio (ie, probability of a negative test result occurring in an infected patient compared to an uninfected patient), calculated as (1 − sensitivity) / specificity.

(Choice B)  0.41 is the overall proportion of positive tests in the sample, calculated as (FP + TP) / (TP + FP + TN + FN).

(Choices C and E)  For a prevalence of 30%, 0.66 is the positive predictive value, PPV = TP / (TP + FP), the probability that a positive test result correctly identifies an infected individual.  0.95 is the negative predictive value, NPV = TN / (TN + FN), the probability that a negative test result correctly identifies an uninfected individual.

Educational objective:
The accuracy of a diagnostic test is the probability that an individual is correctly classified by the test:

Accuracy = (True positives + True negatives) / Total number of individuals tested
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Sensitivity and specificity

questionList.questionText: A study is conducted to determine whether there is an association between congenital heart disease (CHD) and pediatric stroke.  A total of 420 children with a history of ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke and 1,260 age-matched children with no history of stroke participate in the study.  The study results show that CHD is an important childhood risk factor for stroke, and that children who undergo surgical repair for CHD remain at elevated risk outside the perioperative period.  The study concludes that children with CHD would benefit from optimized long-term stroke prevention strategies.  Which of the following statements is most likely true about this study design?
questionList.explanationText:
This study has a case-control design in which participants are initially selected based on their status for a particular disease: case (ie, history of ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke) or control (ie, no history of ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke).

  • Because cases and controls are categorized based on their status for a particular disease, a case-control study is able to evaluate only a single outcome (ie, stroke).

  • Once participants are categorized based on disease status, investigators can evaluate past exposure to ≥1 risk factors of interest (eg, congenital heart disease [CHD]) in each group (Choice A).

These features make case-control studies useful to study diseases that are rare or that have a long latency period between exposure and clinical presentation.

(Choices C and D)  In case-control studies, exposure status to risk factors is typically assessed immediately after subjects have been categorized based on outcome/disease status, so this study design does not require a follow-up (ie, no disproportionate loss to follow-up between cases and controls).  Therefore, case-control studies are usually less time-consuming and less costly compared to other study designs (eg, cohort studies, randomized trials).

Educational objective:
Case-control studies can consider only 1 outcome (ie, disease) per study but can evaluate exposure to ≥1 risk factors.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Study designs

answerChoiceList.choice: Congenital heart disease is the only risk factor for stroke that the study is able to evaluate
Ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke is the only outcome that the study is able to evaluate
The results of the study could be greatly biased due to disproportionate loss to follow-up
The study is likely time-consuming and costly because it requires measuring time to stroke

questionList.questionText: A group of medical geneticists conducts a study to detect microRNA-29a (miR-29a) expression in the plasma of patients with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) and to investigate the clinical significance.  Specimens are collected from patients with LSS, patients with lumbar intervertebral disc herniation, and healthy people.  Reverse transcription-quantitative polymerase chain reaction analysis is used to detect expression levels of miR-29a in plasma.  Several studies on neuromuscular disease models have shown an association between levels of miR-29a and those of matrix metalloproteinase 9 (MMP-9) and a disintegrin and metalloproteinase with thrombospondin motifs 5 (ADAMTS-5), so western blot is used to detect the expression levels of MMP-9 and ADAMTS-5 protein.  Study results reveal that the correlation between the expression levels of miR-29a and MMP-9 is −0.94 (p < 0.01), and that the correlation between the expression levels of miR-29a and ADAMTS-5 is −0.55 (p < 0.01).  Based on these results, which of the following statements is most correct?
questionList.explanationText:
The correlation coefficient (r) describes the direction (ie, negative, positive) and the strength (ie, values closer to 1 indicate stronger relationships) of the linear relationship between 2 quantitative variables, as follows:

  • r < 0 indicates that, as one variable increases, the other variable decreases.  This means that lower values of one variable tend to relate to higher values of the other variable, and vice versa.

  • r > 0 indicates that both variables increase (or decrease) together.  This means that lower values of one variable tend to relate to lower values of the other variable, and vice versa.

In this study, results reveal that the correlation between expression levels of microRNA-29a (miR-29a) and matrix metalloproteinase 9 (MMP-9) in plasma is −0.94 (p < 0.01), and that the correlation between miR-29a and a disintegrin and metalloproteinase with thrombospondin motifs 5 (ADAMTS-5) in plasma is −0.55 (p < 0.01).  Both correlation coefficients are negative (ie, r < 0) and statistically significant (ie, p < 0.05); therefore, there is a significant negative linear relationship between expression levels of miR-29a and expression levels of MMP-9 and ADAMTS-5 in plasma (Choices D and E).

This means that as expression levels of miR-29a increase, expression levels of MMP-9 and ADAMTS-5 decrease.  As a result, lower expression levels of miR-29a in plasma tend to relate to higher levels of expression of MMP-9 and ADAMTS-5 in plasma, and vice versa.  However, a significant linear relationship between 2 variables does not necessarily imply causality (Choice A).

(Choice B)  The values −0.94 and −0.55 are correlation coefficients; they describe the direction and strength of the linear relationship between 2 quantitative variables.  The statistic that describes the percentage of variation in a variable that is explained by another variable is the coefficient of determination, which in many cases is equal to the square of the correlation coefficient (r2, also known as r-squared).

Educational objective:
The correlation coefficient (r) describes the direction (ie, positive, negative) and strength of the linear relationship between 2 quantitative variables.  It does not necessarily imply causality.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Statistical tests

answerChoiceList.choice: A low expression of miR-29a in plasma is a statistically significant cause for low expression of MMP-9 and ADAMTS-5 in plasma
About 94% of the variation in the expression levels of MMP-9 and 55% of the expression levels of ADAMTS-5 are explained by the expression levels of miR-29a in plasma
Lower expression levels of miR-29a in plasma tend to relate to higher levels of expression of MMP-9 and ADAMTS-5 in plasma, and vice versa
There is a statistically significant positive linear relationship between expression levels of miR-29a and expression levels of MMP-9 and ADAMTS-5 in plasma
There is not a statistically significant linear relationship between expression levels of miR-29a and expression levels of MMP-9 and ADAMTS-5 in plasma

questionList.questionText:
A prospective cohort study is conducted to compare the rates of medication errors, adverse drug events (ADEs), and potential ADEs in pediatric and adult hospital settings.  The first cohort consists of 1,120 pediatric patients admitted to a pediatric institution, and the second cohort consists of 1,281 adult patients admitted to an adult institution.  Both cohorts were followed-up for 12 weeks.  A total of 10,778 medication orders from the pediatric institutions and 10,070 medication orders from the adult institutions were reviewed in the study.  Rate of medication errors and ADEs are summarized in the graph below.

Which of the following approximates the relative probability of potential ADEs in the pediatric institution compared to the adult institution?
questionList.explanationText:
This is an example of a cohort study in which 2 different cohorts (eg, patients admitted to a pediatric institution, patients admitted to an adult institution) are followed across time (eg, 12 weeks) to estimate and compare the rate of an outcome of interest (eg, potential adverse drug events [ADEs]).

A common measure used to estimate the relative probability (ie, chance) of an outcome of interest in cohort studies is the relative risk (RR).  RR is equal to the rate of an outcome (eg, potential ADEs) in one cohort (eg, pediatric institution) divided by the rate of the same outcome in a second cohort (eg, adult institution):

RRpediatric vs adult = Ratepediatric / Rateadult

In this case, RRpediatric vs adult must be calculated based on the data shown on the given graph.  The graph reported the following rates of potential ADEs in both institutions:

  • Rate of potential ADEs in the pediatric institution: Ratepediatric = 0.0035 (or 0.35%)
  • Rate of potential ADEs in the adult institution: Rateadult = 0.011 (or 1.10%)

Therefore, RRpediatric vs adult = (0.0035 / 0.011) ≈ 0.32.  This indicates that the rate of potential ADEs in the pediatric institution is a third that in the adult institution; more precisely, the rate of potential ADEs is 68% (ie, 100% − 32%) lower in the pediatric institution compared to the adult institution.

(Choice B)  0.75 is the rate difference of potential ADEs between the adult institution and the pediatric institution expressed as a percentage: RDadult, pediatric = Rateadult − Ratepediatric = 1.1% − 0.35% = 0.75%.  However, the question asks for RRpediatric vs adult.

(Choices C and D)  0.93 is the RR of medication errors (rather than potential ADEs) in the pediatric institution compared to the adult institution (5.30% / 5.70% = 0.93).  1.04 is the RR of ADEs (rather than potential ADEs) in the pediatric institution compared to the adult institution (0.25% / 0.24% = 1.04).

(Choice E)  3.14 is the RR of potential ADEs in the adult institution compared to the pediatric institution: RRadult vs pediatric = 0.011/0.0035 ≈ 3.14 (or 314%).  However, the question asks for RRpediatric vs adult, which is the inverse of RRadult vs pediatric.

Educational objective:
When comparing the relative risk (RR) of the same outcome in 2 cohorts: RR = rate of outcome in cohort 1 / rate of outcome of cohort 2.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Risk

questionList.questionText: An 80-year-old woman with multiple medical problems is admitted to the hospital for evaluation of syncope.  Her heart rate is found to be 36/min.  She was admitted to another hospital recently, then discharged to an acute rehabilitation facility, and then sent to a nursing home.  Review of her history shows that the patient is taking high-dose diltiazem, metoprolol, and atenolol.  Which of the following medication reconciliation interventions is most likely to result in a decrease in adverse drug events and health care utilization?
questionList.explanationText:
Transitions of care - between inpatient and outpatient facilities and between units within inpatient facilities - are potential sources of medical error.  In particular, continuity of care for medications is especially problematic, and errors can lead to an increased risk of medical complications as well as cost.  As a result, most inpatient facilities in the United States have instituted protocols to improve the accuracy of the medication record during transitions of care.

Objective studies to identify best practices for medication reconciliation have been limited, with few interventions confirmed to improve quality of care (Choices A, B, C, and D).  However, interventions that target pharmacy personnel and high-risk patients in particular appear to have the most impact on the quality of patient care.

Educational objective:
Continuity of care for medications at the time of transitions of care, between inpatient and outpatient facilities and within inpatient facilities, is a potential source of medical error.  Interventions that target pharmacy personnel and high-risk patients appear to be the most effective in improving the quality of patient care.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Adverse event

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Hospital-based medication reconciliation practices: a systematic review.

questionList.questionText: A group of infectious disease specialists interested in the rising prevalence of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis conducts a study to determine predisposing risk factors for the condition.  First, they identify 40 patients with multidrug-resistant (MDR) tuberculosis and 64 with pansensitive tuberculosis who were admitted to the hospital over the last 5 years.  They then review the patients' past medical records and consider demographic characteristics, previous anti-tuberculosis treatment, HIV status, and major comorbidities as potential risk factors for MDR tuberculosis development.  They then compare the frequencies of these potential risk factors between the groups.  Which of the following best describes the study design being used?
questionList.explanationText:
Observational epidemiological studies (eg, case series, case control, cohort, and cross-sectional studies) differ from experimental studies (eg, clinical trials) in that the researchers passively observe the study participants rather than monitor the result of a specific intervention.  Observational studies can be subdivided into descriptive and analytical.  Descriptive epidemiology deals with the collection of data to characterize a specific health problem (eg, disease prevalence; incidence rates; distribution over time, location, and demographics).  Analytical epidemiology is used to test hypotheses generated after analyzing the data from descriptive studies (eg, risk factor associations).

Case control studies are analytical observational studies that retrospectively associate outcomes with specific risk factors.  The researcher first begins by selecting cases with a certain outcome of interest (eg, multidrug-resistant tuberculosis [MDR TB] infection) and controls without that outcome (eg, pansensitive tuberculosis infection).  As seen in this example, controls do not need to be disease-free but rather do not have the outcome of interest (eg, controls have pansensitive tuberculosis, not MDR TB).  The cases and controls are then assessed retrospectively for the presence of risk factors (eg, HIV, comorbidities, previous anti-tuberculosis treatment).  Exposure to risk factor status is determined by such activities as personal interviews and analysis of health records and laboratory reports.

The critical distinction between case control and retrospective cohort studies is the order in which outcomes and risk factors are assessed: case control studies first determine the outcome (eg, MDR TB) and then look for associated risk factors (eg, HIV, previous anti-tuberculosis treatment); retrospective cohort studies ascertain risk factor exposure (eg, HIV) and then determine the outcome (eg, MDR TB).

(Choice B)  Cross-sectional studies are observational studies that can be either descriptive or analytical depending on study design.  Since they assess both exposure and outcome at a single point in time, they can show that an association exists but cannot establish causation.

(Choice C)  Prospective cohort studies are analytical observational studies in which a group of exposed and unexposed individuals (eg, patients with and without HIV) is followed prospectively over time for development of the outcome of interest (eg, MDR TB).  Cohort studies are considered stronger than case control and cross sectional studies because of their greater ability to prove causation.

(Choice D)  A randomized control trial is an experimental study that is considered the gold standard for studying the efficacy of a treatment or procedure.  Subjects are randomly assigned to an experimental or control group and monitored for the outcome of interest.  This study design often has the least bias and provides the strongest evidence for a causal relationship.

(Choice E)  A retrospective cohort study is similar to a prospective cohort study except that risk factor exposure and the outcome of interest both occur in the past and are assessed through review of records.  Unlike a case control study, however, risk factor exposure is determined before the outcome is known (ie, first identify patients with and without HIV and then see if they develop MDR TB), thus allowing calculation of the relative risk.

Educational objective:
The critical distinction between case control and retrospective cohort studies is the order in which outcomes and risk factors are assessed.  Case control studies determine the outcome first and then look for associated risk factors; retrospective cohort studies first ascertain risk factor exposure and then determine the outcome.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Study designs

questionList.questionText: A new multidrug chemotherapy regimen significantly prolongs the survival in patients with lung cancer.  If this new regimen is widely implemented, what changes in the prevalence and incidence of lung cancer would you expect?
questionList.explanationText:
It is important to understand the difference between prevalence and incidence, the two basic measures of disease occurrence.  Incidence is the measure of new cases, the rapidity with which they are diagnosed.  Prevalence is the measure of the total number of cases at a particular point in time.  Incidence answers the question: how many new cases of the disease developed in a population during a particular period of time?  Prevalence answers the question: how many cases of the disease exist in a population at a particular point in time?  The relationship between prevalence and incidence can be expressed as:

Prevalence = (Incidence) x (Time)

The incidence of a disease is not changed by any kind of treatment, because the disease has already occurred when treatment is started.  On the other hand, the prevalence may be affected by treatment of the disease.  In this case, treatment of an acute and rapidly fatal disease (e.g., lung cancer) prolonged the survival of patients; however, such treatment did not cure the disease.  This will result in more people having the said disease at one point in time; hence, the prevalence will increase.

(Choices A, B and E) The incidence of a disease is not affected by the treatment.

(Choice D) This statement is not correct because a prolonged time of survival will increase the prevalence.

Educational objective:
Know the difference between incidence and prevalence.  Incidence is the measure of new cases, the rapidity with which they are diagnosed.  Prevalence is the measure of the total number of cases at a particular point in time.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Prevalence and incidence

answerChoiceList.choice: Incidence will decrease, prevalence will decrease
Incidence will increase, prevalence will not increase
Incidence will not change, prevalence will increase
Incidence will not change, prevalence will not change
Incidence will decrease, prevalence will increase

questionList.questionText: A study was conducted to assess the association between L-tryptophan use and the development of Eosinophilia-Myalgia Syndrome (EMS).  Patients with EMS were asked about the use of products containing L-tryptophan during the last 6 months.  At the same time, people without EMS were randomly selected from the same population where the patients came from, and asked about their experience with L-tryptophan containing products within the last 6 months.  The study showed that the use of L-tryptophan is significantly associated with EMS.  Which of the following measures of association are the investigators most likely to report?
questionList.explanationText:
The above case describes a typical case-control study design.  Patients with the disease of interest (cases) and people without the disease (controls) are asked about previous exposure to the variable being studied (L-tryptophan use).  The main measure of association is the exposure odds ratio, in which the exposure of people with the disease (cases) is compared to the exposure of those without the disease (controls).

(Choices A and D)  Incidence measures (e.g., relative risk or relative rate) cannot be directly measured in case-control studies because the people being studied are those who have already developed the disease.  Relative risk and relative rate are calculated in cohort studies, where people are followed over time for the occurrence of the disease.

(Choice B)  Median survival is calculated in cohort studies or clinical trials, and is usually used to compare the median survival times in two or more groups of patients (e.g., receiving a new treatment or placebo).

(Choice E)  Prevalence odds ratio is calculated in cross-sectional studies to compare the prevalence of a disease between different populations.

Educational Objective:
A case-control study is used to compare the exposure of people with the disease (cases) to the exposure of the people without the disease (controls).  The main measure of association is the exposure odds ratio.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Odds ratio

questionList.questionText: The National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) conducted during 2017-2018 estimated that the mean amount of total sugars consumed per day by adults age ≥20 is 107 grams with a 95% confidence interval (CI) of 104-110 grams.  If the confidence level is increased to 99%, which of the following are the most likely lower and upper confidence limits for the 99% CI?
questionList.explanationText:
A C% confidence interval (CI) is a range of plausible values calculated from sample data (eg, sample mean) that captures the true population value (eg, population mean) with a C% confidence level.  The confidence level C refers to how often a CI includes the true population value if the calculation process is repeated multiple times.  A CI to estimate a population value (eg, population mean) is constructed by adding and subtracting a margin of error based on a desired confidence level from the sample value (eg, sample mean).  Therefore, the sample value is always the midpoint of the interval.

The confidence level is equivalent to (1 − α), where α is the significance level (or error rate accepted) for a C% CI.  Conversely, the significance level α = (1 − confidence level) for a C% CI.  For example:

  • A 95% CI has a 95% confidence level and a 100% − 95% = 5% significance level; it captures the central 95% of the distribution.

  • A 99% CI has a 99% confidence level and a 100% − 99% = 1% significance level; it captures the central 99% of the distribution.

Therefore, for the same data, a CI with a greater confidence level is always wider (eg, 99% vs 95% of the distribution) than a CI with a lower confidence level.

In this question, a national survey estimated that the mean amount of total sugars consumed per day by adults age ≥20 is 107 grams (ie, sample mean) with a 95% CI of 104-110 grams.  Increasing the confidence level from a 95% CI to a 99% CI for the same data results in an interval that has the same midpoint (ie, sample mean of 107 grams) (Choices A and E) but is wider than the 95% CI (Choices C and D).  Therefore, the most likely lower and upper confidence limits for the 99% CI are 102 and 112.

Educational objective:
A confidence interval (CI) with a greater confidence level is always wider than a CI with a lower confidence level for the same data, and the sample value (eg, mean) is always the midpoint of the interval.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: P-value and confidence interval

answerChoiceList.choice: 102 108
102 112
104 110
106 108
106 112

questionList.answerHeader:
Lower
confidence limit		Upper
confidence limit

questionList.questionText:
Researchers at a large pharmaceutical company discover a tumor-specific antigen present in high quantities in the serum of patients with pancreatic cancer.  A study is then performed to evaluate serum levels of the tumor marker in patients with and without the disease.  The following curves are generated using the results of the study.

The drug company decides to utilize the newly discovered tumor antigen by creating a screening test for pancreatic cancer.  During preliminary design of the test, the cutoff point for positive/negative results is set at point B.  If the cutoff point is moved from B to A, the sensitivity of the screening test will change in which of the following ways?
questionList.explanationText:
Important parameters of diagnostic tests include the following:

  • True positive (TP) - A patient with a positive test result who actually has the disease.
  • False positive (FP) - A patient with a positive test result who actually does not have the disease.
  • True negative (TN) - A patient with a negative test result who actually does not have the disease.
  • False negative (FN) - A patient with a negative test result who actually has the disease.
  • Sensitivity - The number of patients correctly testing positive for a disease divided by the total number of patients with the disease (TP / [TP + FN]).  High sensitivity means that negative results are less likely to be FNs and more likely to be TNs; thus, a negative result is better able to rule out the disease (SnOut).  Because tests with high sensitivity will correctly identify most of the patients with the disease, sensitivity is very important for screening tests (which need to minimize FNs).
  • Specificity - The number of patients correctly testing negative for a disease divided by the total number of patients without the disease (TN / [TN + FP]).  High specificity means that positive results are less likely to be FPs and more likely to be TPs; thus, a positive result is better able to rule in the disease (SpIn).  Because tests with high specificity will correctly identify most of the patients without the disease, specificity is very important for confirmatory tests (which need to minimize FPs).

In this example, moving the cutoff point from B to A will cause more patients with the disease to test positive (fewer FNs), increasing the sensitivity of the test.  However, as a consequence, more patients without the disease will also test positive (more FPs), resulting in decreased specificity.  Conversely, moving the cutoff point in the other direction (eg, A to B) will increase the number of FNs and decrease the number of FPs, decreasing sensitivity while increasing specificity.

Educational objective:
Changing the cutoff point of a quantitative diagnostic test will inversely affect its sensitivity and specificity.  Typically, lowering the cutoff value will increase sensitivity (fewer false negatives) and decrease specificity (more false positives).  Screening tests need high sensitivity, and confirmatory tests need high specificity.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Sensitivity and specificity

questionList.questionText: A group of researchers at a university hospital plans to conduct a study to determine whether patients with a diagnosis of schizophrenia or bipolar disorder are more likely to have an acute myocardial infarction.  They plan to use hospital administrative data to identify adult patients who were diagnosed with schizophrenia or bipolar disorder between 2008 and 2010 and to select a second group of age- and sex-matched patients without a diagnosis of schizophrenia or bipolar disorder during the same period.  The researchers then plan to examine medical records to determine whether the patients with a diagnosis of schizophrenia or bipolar disorder were more likely to have had an acute myocardial infarction between 2018 and 2020.  Based on this information, which of the following best describes this study design?
questionList.explanationText:
Observational studies are broadly classified as having a descriptive or analytic design.

  • Descriptive designs (eg, case report, case series, cross-sectional) describe patterns of disease in populations by time, place, and person.  These studies help generate hypotheses about associations between risk factors and disease, such as a study showing that a high proportion of people with lung cancer are also smokers.

  • Analytical designs (eg, case-control, cohort, some cross-sectional) test hypotheses about associations between risk factors and disease, such as a study that determines smoking is a risk factor for lung cancer.

This study is an example of a cohort study, an observational analytical design in which potential participants are initially identified as "exposed" or "nonexposed" according to a risk factor (eg, diagnosis of schizophrenia or bipolar disorder between 2008 and 2010).  Once participants are categorized based on exposure status, the occurrence (ie, incidence) of the outcome (eg, acute myocardial infarction [AMI]) within a specific time period (eg, between 2018 and 2020) is determined and compared between groups to estimate the association between risk factor and outcome.

Cohort studies may be either prospective or retrospective:

  • In a retrospective cohort design, the study begins after the outcome has occurred (ie, occurrence of disease in exposed and nonexposed groups is assessed retrospectively), as in this study, which collects data on the occurrence of AMI from a review of medical records between 2018 and 2020 (ie, study will be conducted after AMI has occurred).

  • In a prospective cohort design, the study begins before the outcome has occurred (ie, occurrence of disease in exposed and nonexposed groups is assessed prospectively) (Choice D).

(Choice A)  Case-control studies begin by identifying participants based on outcome status (eg, cases who have had AMI versus controls who have not had AMI) whereas this study initially identified participants based on exposure status.

(Choices B and C)  Case series and cross-sectional studies are examples of descriptive observational designs.  This study examines the association between a risk factor (eg, diagnosis of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder) and outcome (eg, AMI), making it an analytical design.

Educational objective:
A cohort study begins by identifying individuals as exposed or nonexposed to a risk factor and ends by comparing outcome (ie, disease) rates between the exposed and nonexposed groups.  In a prospective cohort design, the study begins before the outcome has occurred whereas in a retrospective cohort design, the study begins after the outcome has occurred.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Study designs
